body: There are many things you can do to help keep your blood glucose levels under control, and here are some links that you may find useful.
intro: Your care team has asked you to use DBm-Health to record your blood glucose levels so they can assess how your treatment is going.

links.intro: I have type 2 diabetes – what can I eat?
links.title: DIABETES.ORG.UK

links.intro: I have type 1 diabetes – what can I eat?
links.title: DIABETES.ORG.UK

links.intro: Free videos for people with, or at risk of, diabetes.
links.title: BDA.UK.COM

title: Managing your blood glucose

body:
Healthy weight can also reduce secondary risks such as strokes and heart disease.

Blood glucose control can become more manageable with a healthy weight. It is important to seek support where there is difficulty losing any extra weight, as this can be very challenging. There are a number of resources on the NHS website and diabetes.org.uk.
intro: Weight management can be a very personal and sensitive issue. A healthy weight in diabetes can have significant benefits for people living with diabetes, especially type 2 diabetes.
title: Weight management

body:
Being active can improve insulin sensitivity and can help manage glucose control in diabetes.

Other benefits of physical activity include maintaining a healthy blood pressure, better quality of sleep as well as improving muscle strength, ligaments and tendons around joints. There are resources about keeping fit on the NHS and diabetes.org.uk. websites.
intro: Keeping fit and remaining active provides people with more energy and helps with feeling positive and maintaining a healthy weight.

links.intro: Exercise and sport for type 1 diabetics
links.title: NHS.UK

title: Activity and fitness
